original_data.question: A 45-year-old G5P4105 presents to her gynecologist’s office with six months of increasingly heavy periods. She now soaks one super absorbent tampon every two hours for five days each cycle. Her cycles have also become irregular, with intermenstrual bleeding for the last two months. She now experiences significant dysmenorrhea, requiring 400 mg ibuprofen every four hours for the majority of each menses. In addition, she reports new onset mild dyspareunia with intercourse and a “heavy feeling” in her pelvis. She has also noticed increased urinary frequency but denies bowel changes. The patient has a past medical history of obesity and type II diabetes on metformin. Her last child was born four years ago, and she has had five spontaneous vaginal deliveries. At this office visit, temperature is 98.5°F (36.9°C), blood pressure is 137/84 mmHg, pulse is 87/min, and respirations are 14/min. Which of the following physical exam findings is most likely to be present in this patient?

model_response:
The patient’s history of increasingly heavy and irregular menses, along with dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia, is suggestive of abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB). AUB can be caused by a variety of factors, including endometrial or cervical polyps, endometrial hyperplasia, endometrial cancer, uterine fibroids, adenomyosis, or infection. The patient’s age, history of obesity, and diabetes mellitus raise concern for endometrial cancer. The physical examination in patients with AUB can be normal, or it can reveal findings such as a globular uterus, suggesting adenomyosis or leiomyomas; an irregular uterus, suggesting a possible polyps or malignancy; or a diffusely enlarged uterus, suggesting a possible uterine leiomyoma. In this case, the patient’s irregularly shaped, 14-week-sized uterus suggests a possible endometrial polyp or endometrial cancer.

Adnexal masses can cause abnormal uterine bleeding, but they are less likely to cause dysmenorrhea and dyspareunia. A 10-week-sized uterus would be expected in a woman of reproductive age with no history of infertility or ovarian failure. A 14-week-sized uterus would be expected in a woman who is approximately 14 weeks pregnant.

The patient’s physical examination is most likely to reveal an irregularly shaped uterus, suggesting a possible polyp or malignancy.

###Answer: OPTION C IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: Qualified medical professionals who specialize in GYNECOLOGY.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
An abnormally high blood pH (usually defined as 7.41 or above). [PMID:24381489]
Of comparatively great physical weight or density.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.
The time for Earth to make a complete rotation on its axis; ordinarily divided into twenty-four hours, equal to 86 400 seconds. This also refers to a specific day.
An event or sequence of events that constitute a round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence.
An event or sequence of events that constitute a round or succession of observable phenomena, recurring usually at regular or approximately regular time intervals and in the same sequence.
Lacking perfect symmetry or evenness.

Abnormal uterine bleeding that is not related to MENSTRUATION, usually in females without regular MENSTRUAL CYCLE. The irregular and unpredictable bleeding usually comes from a dysfunctional ENDOMETRIUM.
One of the 12 divisions of a year as determined by a calendar. It corresponds to the unit of time of approximately to one cycle of the moon's phases, about 30 days or 4 weeks.
Painful menstruation.
A non-steroidal anti-inflammatory agent with analgesic, antipyretic, and anti-inflammatory properties
A unit measure of time equal to 3,600 seconds or 60 minutes. It is approximately 1/24 of a median day.

The periodic shedding of the ENDOMETRIUM and associated menstrual bleeding in the MENSTRUAL CYCLE of humans and primates. Menstruation is due to the decline in circulating PROGESTERONE, and occurs at the late LUTEAL PHASE when LUTEOLYSIS of the CORPUS LUTEUM takes place.
Detailed account or statement or formal record of the proceedings of a meeting or session. May also document status or progress of an activity or research project.
The sexual union of a male and a female, a term used for human only.
Of comparatively great physical weight or density.
Emotional sensations.
The space or compartment surrounded by the pelvic girdle (bony pelvis). It is subdivided into the greater pelvis and LESSER PELVIS. The pelvic girdle is formed by the PELVIC BONES and SACRUM.
Urination at short intervals; it may result from increased urine formation, decreased bladder capacity, or lower urinary tract irritation.
The section of the alimentary canal from the STOMACH to the ANAL CANAL. It includes the LARGE INTESTINE and SMALL INTESTINE.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
A record of a patient's background regarding health and the occurrence of disease events of the individual. In addition, personal medical history may be a variable in epidemiologic studies.

A status with BODY WEIGHT that is grossly above the recommended standards, usually due to accumulation of excess FATS in the body. The standards may vary with age, sex, genetic or cultural background. In the BODY MASS INDEX, a BMI greater than 30.0 kg/m2 is considered obese, and a BMI greater than 40.0 kg/m2 is considered morbidly obese (MORBID OBESITY).

A type of diabetes mellitus that is characterized by insulin resistance or desensitization and increased blood glucose levels. This is a chronic disease that can develop gradually over the life of a patient and can be linked to both environmental factors and heredity.

A biguanide hypoglycemic agent used in the treatment of non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus not responding to dietary modification. Metformin improves glycemic control by improving insulin sensitivity and decreasing intestinal absorption of glucose. (From Martindale, The Extra Pharmacopoeia, 30th ed, p289)
A person 6 to 12 years of age. An individual 2 to 5 years old is CHILD, PRESCHOOL.
The event of being born.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Happening or arising without apparent external cause.
Visits made by patients to health service providers' offices for diagnosis, treatment, and follow-up.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Systematic and thorough inspection of the patient for physical signs of disease or abnormality.
Individuals participating in the health care system for the purpose of receiving therapeutic, diagnostic, or preventive procedures.
